scenes.title: Mirror moment: feeling trapped late-career
scenes.main_point: Ada warns against waking up late in a career feeling trapped by lifestyle and others’ expectations.
scenes.scene_summary: Ada describes the “terrible trap” of going to a job you’re unhappy with because of external pressures, and urges aligning career success with meaningfulness and values.

scenes.title: Curiosity Loop: quick structured outreach
scenes.main_point: Ada explains her Curiosity Loop method for gathering fast, high-quality input.
scenes.scene_summary: Ada recounts emailing 10–11 people with a structured prompt (pick 2–3 topics and explain why), getting rich feedback from ~20 minutes of work.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
Ada at her desk drafting and sending an email with a structured prompt, a list of 2–3 topics visible on her screen.
As she hits send, replies begin appearing in her inbox, with a note about anonymized feedback.

scenes.title: How to structure it: good question + right people
scenes.main_point: Ada breaks down the mechanics: ask a good, unbiased question and curate who you ask.
scenes.scene_summary: She contrasts a vague question with a specific one, then explains choosing both subject-matter experts and people who know you, and keeping the ask lightweight to reduce cognitive load.
key_elements: Bad vs good question examples on screen
Two criteria for advisors (expertise + knows you)

Beside it, she writes two advisor criteria: “expertise” and “knows you,” and a small note: “keep the ask lightweight,” looking focused.

scenes.title: Personal example: estate planning age debate
scenes.main_point: Curiosity Loops also work for personal decisions, like estate planning for a child.
scenes.scene_summary: Ada shares how she and her partner asked trusted people about when their daughter should inherit (18 vs 25), learned no one chose 18, and heard about executive function peaking around 30.

The group’s responses cluster away from 18, and one person mentions executive function peaking around 30; the parents look thoughtful.

scenes.title: Values exercise: building an inner scorecard
scenes.main_point: Ada introduces a values-picking exercise to create an internal decision scorecard.
scenes.scene_summary: Lenny shares his values list (adventure, optimism, treat others well, keep improving, generosity, plus “do what you need then what you want”), and they apply it to his “say yes vs no” dilemma around projects and a new child.
key_elements: Discussion of saying no to opportunities

scenes.title: Early career strategy: explore then exploit
scenes.main_point: Ada outlines her early-career framework of exploration followed by focused exploitation.
scenes.scene_summary: Ada summarizes moving from Microsoft to a startup to founding Connected, then using LinkedIn intentionally to learn growth and subscriptions—optimizing for learning over title—leading to SurveyMonkey recruiting her for needed experiences.
key_elements: Timeline of roles (Microsoft → startup → founder → LinkedIn → SurveyMonkey)
